source:
In this work book I will connect to the Companies House API and see what data is avaliable. I am especially interested in financial data like turnover, gross profit, current assets etc. 

Here is link to the official API documentation: https://developer.companieshouse.gov.uk/api/docs/

In order to start using the API you will need to set up Companies House account. This can be done here https://developer.companieshouse.gov.uk/developer/applications Don't worry this process is automated and a couple seconds later you will have your API key. 

If you are having any problems check out getting started guide - https://developer.companieshouse.gov.uk/api/docs/index/gettingStarted.html
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
### Accessing CH API with python wraper chwrapper
You can download Companies House API python wrapper called chwrapper from https://pypi.org/project/chwrapper/

Unfortunately documentaion for this wrapper is very limmited - https://chwrapper.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/quickstart.html

Will need to figure out how it works by trying to call API.
import chwrapper
search_client = chwrapper.Search(access_token='Gaev32xRla-4_G6lXv5mhOJEjyFQKrLH1HHlVt2M')

source: response = search_client.search_companies('dyson')
response.json()
Looks like this way we can search for a company by name and get its data.

Supported end points include: 
    - Search for companies by name
    - Search for officers by name
    - Search for officer appointments by officer number
    - Search for company addresses by company number 
    - Search for company profile by company number 
    - Search for insolvency records by company number
    - Search for a company's filing history
    - Search for charges against a company
    - Search for officers registered against a company
    - Search for disqualified officers by their ID number
    - Search for all persons of significant control of a company
    - Search for a single person with significant control of a company
    - Search for documents by document ID
    
Documentation does not provide exsample usage for the above queries.
So I decided to use another wrapper called companies-house.
###Â Accessing CH API with python wraper companies-house 0.1.2

Let' get s data using python wrapper companies-house 0.1.2. 

Documentation avaliable here - https://pypi.org/project/companies-house/
from companies_house.api import CompaniesHouseAPI
ch = CompaniesHouseAPI('Gaev32xRla-4_G6lXv5mhOJEjyFQKrLH1HHlVt2M')

source: ch_number = '02627406'
ch.get_company(ch_number)
#### Flatten and Follow_Links - companies-house 0.1.2

Python wrapper companies-house 0.1.2 additionally gives you the following functionality for each function:

* flatten: Flatten the returned dict (to allow use in flat files, pandas etc.)

* follow_links: API resources are linked by a links attribute. If you set follow_links to true, those are automatically followed and merged into the main object, to form a deeper, more comprehensive object. Use with care as there are currently no checks for recursion!
Let's try Flatten and see what it does.

source: ch.get_company(ch_number, flatten=True)

Now it is time to make API result a dataframe using from_dict(). We have to specify orientation of the data as orient='index'. Since the default parameter orient='columns' does not work on flattened data.

# preventing pandas from trancating dataframe
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)  
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)

source:
data = ch.get_company(ch_number, follow_links=True, flatten=True)

df_02627406 = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(data, orient='index')

df_02627406

Parameter follow_links gets us additional data about the company but does not pull financial history of the company. 

Next we will see what get_company_filing_history() gets us for DYSON LIMITED (02627406) from the API.

In order to use get_company_filing_history() we need additional parametrer transaction_id. This can be found in the dataframe above. Transaction id is unique for each filling.

transaction_id = 'MzI0NTI5OTU1OGFkaXF6a2N4'

data = ch.get_company_filing_history(ch_number, transaction_id, flatten=True)

df_filing_h_02627406 = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(data, orient='index')

df_filing_h_02627406

We are not getting any financial data from the accounts since DYSON LIMITED (02627406) only files accounts in PDF's. At the minute Companies House API providces captured financial data from the accounts only when company files accounts in iXBRL format.
BBC Limited (06500244) files its accounts in PDF and iXBRL formats. So this company will be better exsaple for testing get_company_filing_history().

Again no luck with getting balance sheet and profit and loss data. This time because company is filling dormant acccounts.

I now downloaded one of iXBRL monthly files and found a company that files accounts in iXBRL format with actual financial data. 

It is Davey and Company London Limited (00107693).

transaction_id = 'MzIyNjQ2OTg4OGFkaXF6a2N4'

data = ch.get_company_filing_history(ch_number, transaction_id, flatten=True)

df_filing_h_00107693 = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(data, orient='index')

df_filing_h_00107693
And still no  balance sheet and profit and loss data even though accounts 2018-12-31 do have this data. Not sure why python wrapper does not get us such data.

Exsample of CH url for accounts: 

https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/00107693/filing-history/MzIyNjQ2OTg4OGFkaXF6a2N4/document?format=xhtml&download=1

https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk Plus whats in links__self

I did a bit of investigation and it turns out that financial data from iXBRL formats is not included in the API by Companies House. Please see below link to the Companies House forum where addition of such data was requested by developers community. 

https://forum.aws.chdev.org/t/will-company-financial-information-be-available/190

Looks like if I want to get financial data like turnover, gross profit, current assets etc. I will need to scrape it from iXBRL accounts from files made avaliable by the Companies House to the public. http://download.companieshouse.gov.uk/en_accountsdata.html
